Award.AwardTitle: The 2011 Joint Annual Conference of the National Society of Black Physicists and the National Society of Hispanic Physicists
Award.AbstractNarration: This NSF grant will support a majority of costs not covered by program income for the 2011 Joint Annual Conference of the National Society of Black Physicists (NSBP) and the National Society of Hispanic Physicists (NSHP). Minorities are very under-represented in the sciences and particularly in the field of physics, broadly defined. The overarching goal is to increase the number of students who graduate in physics and closely related fields by providing them with an opportunity to participate in a friendly and supportive Conference environment that combines forefront research with an extensive program of professional development. We estimate six hundred participants, three hundred of whom will be students, who, because the Conference is organized by NSBP and NSHP and heavily advertised to their membership, will be predominantly minorities. The Conference will offer extensive opportunities for the attendees to network with their peers to exchange not only scientific knowledge but also the tacit knowledge needed to succeed in the profession of physics. Our target is for the Conference to take place in April 2011, in a venue that will be determined by reasonable hotel cost and proximity to a significant scientific laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
African-Americans, Hispanics, and Native Americans are very underrepresented in the fields of physics, astronomy, and related fields in comparison to the population fraction and in comparison to other science and engineering fields. To address this, the Joint Annual Conference of the National Society of Black Physicists (NSBP) and the National Society of Hispanic Physicists (NSHP) brings together the largest gathering of minority physicists and astronomers in the world. The 2011 conference was held September 21-24 at the Renaissance Hotel in Austin, Texas. Attendance was over 500 attendees, with 251 being students and 24 being postdoctoral fellows. The remainder were faculty and representatives of federal agencies and research organizations (corporate and academic). The sessions covered such disciplines as acoustics; astronomy and astrophysics; atomic, molecular and optical physics; chemical and biological physics; nuclear and particle physics; photonics and other topics. The program allowed for student?presented posters and oral presentations in all disciplines. A significant part of the program was dedicated to student professional development including several sessions designed to help students identify mentors, sessions on mentoring, sessions on the GRE, a session on undergraduate Electricity and Magnetism, sessions on Bridge Programs (programs aimed at transitioning undergraduates into graduate school, and others focused on providing support and guidance to students and postdoctoral fellows.

A survey of attendees indicates a very high level of satisfaction with the program, the organization of the conference, and the venue. 

A new management approach was adopted for this meeting. The grant was awarded to the Southeastern Research Association (SURA), which has expertise in grant management and has professional staff to assist with the management. A Conference Executive Committee appointed by SURA and composed of SURA, NSHP, and NSBP representatives was in charge of policy matters. The program for the Conference was the responsibility of the Program Committee. This Committee was largely a continuation of the previous program committee and thus had scientific expertise, experience in creating the program, and experience in the operational aspects of the meeting. SURA was ultimately responsible for the entire project. In addition to NSF, the Conference also received support from the University of Texas at Austin and IBM Corporation.

In summary, a very successful conference designed to increase the number of minority students graduating in the areas of physics, broadly defined, and astronomy was organized under a new management system and was very successful at meeting the desires of the students and postdocs.
